metadata.synopsis: 10-year-old Chihiro (Daveigh Chase) moves with her parents to a new home in the Japanese countryside. After taking a wrong turn down a wooded path, Chihiro and her parents discover an amusement park with a stall containing an assortment of food. To her surprise, Chihiro's parents begin eating and then transform into pigs. In this supernatural realm, Chihiro encounters a host of characters and endures labor in a bathhouse for spirits, awaiting a reunion with her parents.

reviews: Its predilection for comical freakishness undeniably sets it apart.
It is a mix of the real and the surreal, enough to captivate the younger audiences and haunt the older ones.
Miyazaki's animation is breathtakingly beautiful and incredibly intricate.
Creative beyond all reason or expectation, this deserving winner of the Best Animated Feature Oscar is a phenomenal achievement.
Miyazaki has made a loopy, demanding work of art that asks your inner child to come out and play. There are few high-wire acts in all of moviedom as satisfying as that.
Probably the most original movie I've ever seen.
Spirited Away doesn't talk down to its young audience, or treat its viewers delicately.
he box office champion in Japan, this film is a genuine work of art.
[VIDEO ESSAY] Animation legend Hayao Miyazaki's divinely imaginative display of madcap surrealism is virtuosic in this episodic coming of age classic.
Part Alice in Wonderland and part Hansel and Gretel...
Knock me down with a feather, it turns out to be terrific; maybe not a masterpiece, but certainly aglitter with invention, excitement and a mysterious kind of wit.
Vivid, amusing and genuinely awe-inspiring.
Writer-director Hayao Miyazaki, who previously made the impressive Princess Mononoke, has created a wonderfully bizarre world filled with a gallery of creepy, and some not so-creepy, characters.
This one is an event, a huge accomplishment in the world of traditional animation and a powerful rebuttal to the notion that films for children must be simplistic and visually dull.
Chihiro's escapades don't always proceed one from the other, but let yourself go and you'll be swept away as well.
The impressive watercolour backgrounds and intense focus on the smallest details make Spirited Away more than a kid's flick. It will grab hold and impress, amaze and entertain before letting you go.
Spirited Away is unquestionably the best animated feature since Brad Bird's The Iron Giant.
What it does have is the same kind of free-floating, imaginative animation, taking wing for even wilder flights of fantasy.
Artful but not arty, Spirited Away is a handcrafted cartoon, as personal as an Utamaro painting, yet its breadth and heart give it an appeal that should touch American viewers of all ages.
Spirited Away is a masterwork, the latest and best in a long line from Japan's premieranimator.
publisher: data-qa="review-critic-publication">The Magazine of Fantasy & Science Fiction
